name: My Favorite Monsters Trivia Game | Mythology Mixture | 10 Questions

questions.text: What was the name of the Egyptian bird associated with the worship of Heliopolis?
questions.explanation:
Bennu.

	The Bennu bird is an Egyptian equivalent of the phoenix.

questions.text: In Ctesias' 'Persica', a creature possessing the body of a lion and a face of a man was described. Even the veracious Herodotus would admit to the reality of this beast...what was the creature called?
questions.explanation:
Manticore.

	The manticore has the body of a lion, the head of a human and the tail of a scorpion.

questions.text: In an ancient country, large, purple-headed- horses were quite abundant. They possessed blue eyes and attacked men by wildly kicking them....what country were they from?
questions.explanation:
India.

	This is part of the proto-Hindu mythological belief system.

questions.text: In Ethiopia, the Krokottas had a secret way of luring men and then devouring them. How did they attract them?
questions.explanation:
Spoke.

	Something akin to the sirens of Greek myth, who lured sailors with their beautiful singing voices.

questions.text: In Lucan's 'Pharsalia' which two creatures were spawned, as Perseus flew over Libya with the dripping blood of Medusa ?
questions.explanation:
Amphisbaena and basilisk.

	An amphisbaena is a serpent of myth that has a head on each end.  There is a modern species of lizard called the amphisbaenia that indeed has a false head as a tail.

questions.text: Lucian was an earnest and a great, Greek writer. In his 'True Story', his crew and mates are swallowed by a large whale measuring how many miles in length?
questions.explanation:
150.

	Very similar to the Jonah tale of Hebrew mythology.

questions.text: The Cartazonus was said to be invincible with its one-horn on its head.  From which country was this version of the unicorn seen?
questions.explanation:
India.

	Practically every myth system around the world has a version of the unicorn, or the single-horned creature.

questions.text: Who was considered the first Encyclopedist, as well as the compiler of the 'Physiologus of Bestiary' ca. 560-636?
questions.explanation:
Isidore of Seville.

	Isidore was one of the most brilliant minds of the Middle Ages.  Now a Catholic saint, he wrote the 'Chronica Majora', a history of the world.

questions.text: In Tibetan myth, they talk of a mysterious manlike creature that wanders the Himalayas.  We sometimes call it the 'abominable snowman', but what do the Tibetans call it?
questions.explanation:
Yeti.

	Yeti (or 'yeh-teh') literally means 'small, manlike creature' in the Tibetan language.

questions.text: In Greek myth, what was the largest bird in heaven, the dispenser of light?
questions.explanation:
Gryphon.

	The name is also spelled 'griffin' or 'griffon'.  The gryphon had a head like an eagle (and wings) and a lion's body. Thanks for playing, I hope you have enjoyed this quiz.
